Award.AwardTitle: Immigrant Entrepreneurship, Innovation, and Job Creation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
High-skilled immigrant entrepreneurs contribute to U.S. economy by starting companies that create jobs and promote innovation. Much of our current understanding of the contribution of highly skilled entrepreneurs is based on popular accounts as available data sources do not allow for the identification of entrepreneurial firms in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. To provide empirical evidence this project will create new databases and new methods that will define high-skilled immigrant entrepreneurs in a systematic and rigorous manner. The project will then examine the choices faced by immigrants when deciding to start a new firm versus the decision to be employed by a larger corporation. Beyond the decision to start a firm the project will examine potential constraints that limit the growth and expansion of firms started by high-skilled immigrant entrepreneurs when compared to similar firms. The project contributes an understanding of the contribution of new firms started by highly skilled immigrants to the pace and direction of U.S. innovation and employment growth and makes suggestions to address policies that constrain the growth of these firms.

The project creates a longitudinal data platform to answer specific questions both at the person- and firm-level using micro-data on individuals and firms, including the Longitudinal Employer ? Household Dynamics (LEHD), Longitudinal Business Database (LBD), the Decennial Censuses and the American Community Surveys (ACS). The work covers a long time horizon (1991-2011), containing the most recent recession and initial recovery period. The specific research questions the project addresses include, the trends in the number, size, location and type of firms founded by immigrants; the number and quality of jobs created by those firms; the pathways leading immigrants into entrepreneurship; and, innovation patterns in the new start-ups. The LEHD based measures of immigrant entrepreneurs constructed under this project provide the basis for future research on this topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do immigrant entrepreneurs affect firm creation, innovation, and job growth in the U.S. economy?  Despite the continuous and often heated debate about the appropriate rate and type of immigration for America, there has been little previous research related to the economic impact of immigrant entrepreneurs. This project provided the first comprehensive estimates of the effects of immigrants on firm starts and job creation using large-scale administrative and survey data linked to universal panel data on all U.S. private employer firms. The firm-level survey data came from the Survey of Business Owners (SBO) and the Annual Survey of Entrepreneurs (ASE), while the linked employer-employee data were assembled by the Census Bureau and based on the administrative records from state-level unemployment insurance (UI) programs and the Social Security Administration.

We created multiple linkages to improve the person-level detail and the firm-level longitudinal dimension of our data. This database construction was essential for describing the characteristics of new firms and their founders and for quantifying their long-run success in terms of firm survival and growth. In addition, we linked area-level information on the demographic makeup of the local workforce, state-level policies towards immigrants, and other immigration-related policy measures such as the E-Verify program.

Several key findings emerged from the research.

  • Immigrants start a large and growing share of new employer firms in the United States. Between 1995 and 2012, the share grew from 16% to 25%. The role of immigrant entrepreneurs is equally large (or more so) in the high-tech sector as in low-tech sectors.
  • Immigrant-founded firms are unequally distributed across the country, with large differences across U.S. cities and states in terms of the share of businesses owned by immigrants. But in all U.S. states, immigrants start more firms on a per capita basis than natives.
  • The job creation share of immigrant entrepreneurs follows closely the firm creation share. Immigrant-owned firms hire slightly fewer employees per firm at the start, but the difference mostly comes from differential location and industry concentration of the firms. Jobs created by immigrant entrepreneurs pay somewhat less and provide fewer employee benefits, largely explained by their concentration in certain sectors.
  • Immigrant-founded firms have substantially higher rates of global engagement, ranging from the exporting of goods to the establishment of overseas operations.
  • Immigrant groups vary widely in terms of who they hire as early employees in these start-ups. Some founders (e.g., those migrating from China and Vietnam) hire almost half of their early employees from the own ethnic group, and the share of co-ethnic hiring changes little as the firm ages. Conversely, other immigrant groups (e.g., those from Germany and Canada) hire mostly American workers and/or workers from other ethnicities than their own.
  • The degree of co-ethnic hiring is related to the availability of co-ethic labor in the relevant labor market and sector, language similarities, and the group’s cultural similarity to the United States. In the medium-run, co-ethnic hiring improves firm survival and employment growth when the business is surrounded by a large number of co-ethnic workers.

In addition to our work on large-scale administrative and survey data, we surveyed start-up founders, CEOs, inventors, and non-inventor employees in a large multi-city co-working facility. Within the same firms, we find significant differences in personality traits across individuals in the four roles. For example, founders show much greater tolerance for risk compared to the other groups as well as greater self-efficacy and openness.

Our research shows that immigrant founders and employees value networking capabilities more than natives, and the networks developed by immigrants tend to be larger within the co-working facility. They show substantially greater rates of giving and receiving advice than natives for six surveyed factors: business operations, venture, financing, technology, suppliers, people to recruit, and customers. These findings have implications for sorting by individuals into entrepreneurship, knowledge spillovers, and allocation of talent in the economy.

Several publications resulted from the research conducted in this project, including a popular press book, peer-reviewed journal publications, book chapters, and working papers. The PI testified as a witness in the U.S. Congress on our findings related to the economic impacts of immigrant entrepreneurs. The findings were also publicized in numerous blogs, newspaper articles, radio and podcast interviews, and other outlets directed at general audiences.

This research has advanced understanding on the importance of immigrant entrepreneurs and business owners in the U.S. economy, how their effect varies with the characteristics of the firms and firm owners, and the role of various policy factors in mediating that impact. More broadly, the project has supported research on theoretical models of the start-up process, the personality variations among start-up founders and their employees, immigration policies for entrepreneurs and high-skilled workers across the globe, and a broader description of the changing nature of firm founders and owners over the last two decades in the United States.
